It is apparent most do not know how the Year Round School system works. A student is not in school for the whole year. Each school or town is set up into a 4 block system. While 3 blocks are attending school, the 1 block is out. It works like this: basically 3 months in school, 3 weeks off, for the whole 12 months of the year. This is the way our town/school were set up. This opens up a vast amount of opportunities for the students as well as the teachers! Students can be involved all year in projects or sports, they can catch attend a class during the "off" time if they need to catch up, families are not limited to the summer for vacation time, they are not home in front of a t.v. or video game for 12 weeks during the summer! Teachers are employed all year, they can take vacations though out the whole year, teachers can help students who need the extra help. There is less need for parents to try to find a sitter for 12 or more weeks for younger kids. The "Summer Job" issue is really not a problem, most employers liked the idea of having the students during the 3 week "off time", they worked with every one and they even kept some students employed longer then just for the summer. You people really need to know how the system works before you give you opinion on some thing you know nothing about. It is time to grow and to grow up.  As a student, I attended a YR school. As an adult and parent, I wish we had the YRS. I have seen many students in my childrens classes who whould have benifited greatly from the YRS. It is time we start looking at the progress the world around us has made and then look in the mirror. We need to catch up!

I don't have any personal experience with year-round school, but back in the '90s my local school district tried year-round school at some schools. This meant that some households had students who did not attend the same school and thus had some children on vacation while the rest were still in school.
 
 Furthermore, year-round school here was simply spreading out the summer vacation over the calendar year. Students still only spent 180 days in school.
 
 I am in favor of year-round school if it allows students to enter at a later age or graduate at an earlier age because the K-12 180 day school schedule is condensed so the school facilities are used more efficiently.
 
 Alternatively I support year-round school with a longer school year and a reduction of course repetition so schools can have an extensive college prep program. I have designed such a curriculum for a private school I am trying to open. The calendar year will have five 9-week academic terms with a 1-3 week break between terms. Students will be in school for 48 terms and will be prepared to take at least 8 AP exams by the time they graduate.

Well, I had soome experience with Year-round school. From Kindergarten to Third Grade I lived in florida and went to a school that had Year-round school, but unfortunately we had to move to Missouri and couldn't find a local one that had it. I really liked it.
 
 Basically how it went was we would have about six weeks off in the summer, four weeks off in the winter, and two to three weeks off in the Spring and in the Fall, giving us actually more than most public schools. The really good thing about the spring and fall breaks was that if you wanted to go somewhere on vacation (to a themepark like Disneyworld, or out to the beaches on the East or west coach), there would hardly be anyone else there - imagine not having to wait in line at a theme park (a novel experiene for some, I would bet).
 
 As for other benefits, it helps prevent burnout from months of school at a time with few to no breaks. It also could reduce the amount of students that get away from the phys ed and become couch potatoes (probably a large cause of our obese nation). The most important, however, is that it reduces the amount of time you are out of the classroom, thus reducing the amount of information you forget, and in turn reducing the amount of time wasted after each break by the teacher going through a comprehensive review.

The current standard school year has 4 academic terms here (9-weeks each to give 180 days per calendar year in school). Adding an extra academic term would still leave a 4 week summer vacation (with 2 weeks at Christmas and 1 week at Easter). So extending the school year and keeping the existing curriculum would reduce the current 13 calendar years for K-12 by more than 31 months. Students could then enroll at a later age or graduate at an earlier age so this would have the same effect as building new schools. Of course the teachers' union would pitch an ever-loving fit.
